channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: The first person to receive a genetically modified pig kidney transplant has died
item.description: Richard Slayman died almost two months after the historic procedure, the Boston hospital where he had the transplant said Saturday. At 62, he had the transplant to treat his end-stage kidney disease.
item.content:encoded:
Richard Slayman died almost two months after the historic procedure, the Boston hospital where he had the transplant said Saturday. At 62, he had the transplant to treat his end-stage kidney disease.

(Image credit: Michelle Rose)
item.dc:creator: Emma Bowman

item.title: Putin replaces his defense minister as he starts his 5th term in office
item.description: Putin proposed Andrei Belousov, who until recently served as the first deputy prime minister, to replace Sergei Shoigu in a Cabinet shakeup.
item.content:encoded:
Putin proposed Andrei Belousov, who until recently served as the first deputy prime minister, to replace Sergei Shoigu in a Cabinet shakeup.

(Image credit: Alexander Zemlianichenko)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: There's still a chance to see the Northern Lights from lower latitudes
item.description: The solar storm that's pushing sightings of the Northern Lights to lower latitudes is forecast to continue into the coming days, but its impact has likely peaked.
item.content:encoded:
The solar storm that's pushing sightings of the Northern Lights to lower latitudes is forecast to continue into the coming days, but its impact has likely peaked.

(Image credit: Kyle Green)
item.dc:creator: John Helton

item.title: Student protests caused mostly minor disruptions at several graduation ceremonies
item.description: From California to North Carolina, students staged chants and walkouts over the weekend in protest of Israel's ongoing military offensive in Gaza.
item.content:encoded:
From California to North Carolina, students staged chants and walkouts over the weekend in protest of Israel's ongoing military offensive in Gaza.

(Image credit: Brandon Bell)
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Rosman

item.title: A tribe in Maine is using opioid settlement funds on a sweat lodge to treat addiction
item.description: Hundreds of Native American tribes are getting money from lawsuit settlements with opioid companies. Some are investing the new funds in traditional healing practices to treat addiction.
item.content:encoded: Hundreds of Native American tribes are getting money from lawsuit settlements with opioid companies. Some are investing the new funds in traditional healing practices to treat addiction.
item.dc:creator: Aneri Pattani

item.title: Kenya's Samburu boys share a sacred bond. Why one teen broke with the brotherhood
item.description: After initiation rites – including circumcision – the boys leave their families to take charge of the herds, driving them high into the mountains. It's a way of life that climate change is testing.
item.content:encoded:
After initiation rites – including circumcision – the boys leave their families to take charge of the herds, driving them high into the mountains. It's a way of life that climate change is testing.

(Image credit: Claire Harbage)
item.dc:creator: Nurith Aizenman

item.title: A car-free town in the Amazon serves lessons for pedaling to net zero emissions
item.description: Afuá, a remote town in the Brazilian Amazon, banned motor vehicles over 20 years ago. Writer Mac Margolis and photographer Stefan Kolumban paid the town a visit to see what life is like.
item.content:encoded:
Since 2002, this city on the banks of the Amazon River has been famously off limits to motor vehicles.'/>

Afuá, a remote town in the Brazilian Amazon, banned motor vehicles over 20 years ago. Writer Mac Margolis and photographer Stefan Kolumban paid the town a visit to see what life is like.
item.dc:creator: Mac Margolis

item.title: Controlled demolition planned at Baltimore bridge collapse site
item.description: After weeks of preparation, crews are scheduled to conduct a controlled demolition to break down the largest remaining span of the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge in Maryland.
item.content:encoded:
After weeks of preparation, crews are scheduled to conduct a controlled demolition to break down the largest remaining span of the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge in Maryland.

(Image credit: Christopher Rosario)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Roger Corman, the B-movie legend who launched A-list careers, dies at 98
item.description: Over some five decades, Corman filled America's drive-ins with hundreds of low-budget movies. Many of Hollywood's most respected directors have at least one Corman picture buried in their resumes.
item.content:encoded:
Over some five decades, Corman filled America's drive-ins with hundreds of low-budget movies. Many of Hollywood's most respected directors have at least one Corman picture buried in their resumes.

(Image credit: Kevork Djansezian)
item.dc:creator: Neda Ulaby

item.title: Switzerland's Nemo wins Eurovision 2024 in a year of protests
item.description: The Swiss singer and rapper was one of two nonbinary artists in the finals at this year's event held in Malmo, Sweden. Meanwhile, protesters called for Israel's disqualification from the contest.
item.content:encoded:
The Swiss singer and rapper was one of two nonbinary artists in the finals at this year's event held in Malmo, Sweden. Meanwhile, protesters called for Israel's disqualification from the contest.

(Image credit: Martin Meissner)
item.dc:creator: Chloe Veltman
